text:
Getting started with
AWS Management Portal for vCenter
AWS Management Portal for vCenter

enables you to manage
your AWS resources
using VMware vCenter.

In this video
we will explain the benefits

of AWS Management Portal
for vCenter.

And will demonstrate
how to use it to perform the tasks

most commonly done
by virtual machine administrators.
AWS Management Portal for vCenter

provides a simple,
easy-to-use interface

for creating and managing
AWS resources
from VMware vCenter.

The portal installs
as a vCenter plug-in

within your existing
vCenter environment.

And it offers
a familiar look and feel

for experienced
to vCenter administrators.
It includes integrated support

from migrating
vCenter virtual machines

to compute instances
in Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud,
Amazon EC2.

As well as creating new compute
instances from templates.

You can also use the portal
to administer EC2 instances,

both those you migrated
from vCenter VMs

and those you created
from templates.

Because AWS Management Portal
for vCenter

offers access to AWS regions
around the world

you can use it to create
and manage EC2 instances

that are close
to your on-premises computing
and close to your customers.

The inventory is the fundamental way
VMware vCenter organizes resources.

Inventories present virtual machines
and many other vCenter concepts
in a hierarchical way.
AWS Management Portal for vCenter

also presents the elements
you can manage
in a hierarchical inventory.
Let's examine these elements.

The AWS cloud is made up
of AWS regions around the world.

AWS Management Portal makes it easy
for you to use any of these regions.
To start using a new AWS region

you or your vCenter administrator
will define an environment in it.

That is associated
with your AWS account.

An environment gathers together
one or more templates,

which you will use to create
new compute instances
as well as one or more IP subnets.
Templates also service folders

for the compute instances
you create from them.

Compute instances created by importing
from vCenter virtual machines

appear under a special
imported instances folder.

Now let's see a demonstration
of the day-to-day tasks

for which a vCenter administrator
would use AWS Management Portal.

In this demonstration we will start
with an environment
that's already been configured.

First let's migrate the vCenter VM
to an Amazon EC2 instance.

We'll select the desired VM
inside vCenters inventory

after having confirmed
that the guest operating system

inside the VM is configured
to get its IP address from DHCP
and that the VM is stopped.

Now right click the VM
and then click Migrate VM to EC2.

Select the guest operating system
running inside the VM.
Then choose an AWS region.

vCenter will offer the environments
in that AWS region
to which you have access.
Choose one.
Select a subnet for the instance.

Check with your administrator
if you need more information

about this subnet's
address spaces and connectivity.
Select an instance type.

Amazon EC2 instance types
comprise varying combinations

of CPU, memory, storage
and networking capacity.

You may optionally
enter a private IP address.

If you don't specify
a private IP address,

AWS Management Portal
will select one for you
from the appropriate subnet range.

Now choose a security group
for the instance.
Security groups like firewalls

limit access
to particular network ports.

Your administrator
can give more information

about the security groups
already defined in this environment
or define new ones.
Now click Migrate to EC2.
After the migrate task begins,
we display an import task ID.
Note to this ID:

if you'd like to monitor
the migrate task,

the migration happens
in the background

so there was no need
to leave the vCenter client open
while them migration runs.
Once the migration is complete,

the portal shows
the newly created instance
and we can administer it.

Next, let's deploy a new
EC2 compute instance

from a template provided to you
by your administrator.

From vCenter click Home
and then click AWS Management Portal.

From the dashboard
expand the region

and the environment
for the new instance.
Then select the template.

On the Getting Started tab
click Deploy an instance.

Templates encompass
a software image

called an Amazon Machine Image
or AMI,

which is like a Golden Master
in VMware terms,
as well as a choice of subnet

and other important
configuration choices.

Enter a useful name
for the instance in the name field.

You can specify one or more tags
for the instance.

Your AWS bill will use these tags
to help you understand your charges.

Select a subnet for the instance
and then click Next.

Review the configuration
for your instance.

When you are ready to deploy
the instance, click Finish.

Your instance will be launched
and you can administer it

through AWS Management
Portal's inventory.
AWS Management Portal for vCenter

is the simplest
and most user-friendly option
for migrating VMs to AWS.

The tool offers you access
to AWS regions around the world.

The portal is
at no additional charge.

You pay only
for the resources you'd use.

You can learn more about
the portal and its capabilities
at the URLs shown.
This concludes our video.
